In 2011, the first MXene Ti3C2 was obtained by selectively etching away the Al element in Ti3AlC2 by HF acid. Reproduced with permission [207]. Copyright 2011, WILEY-VCH. In 2012, theory and experiments shown that MXene was a promising transition metal carbide anode for LIBs. Reproduced with permission [44]. Copyright 2012, American Chemical Society. In 2013, MXene was expected to be a good candidate for reversible hydrogen storage materials. Reproduced with permission [18]. Copyright 2013, American Chemical Society. In 2014, it is theoretically predicted that MXene can be employed as an electrode for non-lithium-ion batteries. Reproduced with permission [49]. Copyright 2014, American Chemical Society. Additionally, high capacitance of surface-modified 2D MXene in acidic electrolyte was prepared. Reproduced with permission [208]. Copyright 2014, Elsevier. In 2015, MXene Ti3C2 had adsorption effect on heavy-metal (Pb). Reproduced with permission [17]. Copyright 2015, American Chemical Society. And large-scale delamination of MXene was obtained by reacting MXene with an organic base. Reproduced with permission [209]. Copyright 2015, The Royal Society of Chemistry. In 2016, MXene/CNTs and Nb2O5@Nb4C3T x heterostructures were synthesized via different technologies for SIBs and LIBs. Reproduced with permission [85,210]. Copyright 2016, WILEY-VCH and Elsevier. In 2017, MXene Ti3C2 was used for metal Li anode protection. Reproduced with permission [211]. Copyright 2017, Elsevier. Alkalized Ti3C2 MXene nanoribbons with expanded interlayer spacing for high-capacity SIBs and KIBs were synthesized. Reproduced with permission [167]. Copyright 2017, Elsevier. In 2018, the vertically aligned was achieved by mechanical shearing of a discotic lamellar liquid–crystal phase of Ti3C2T x , and the resulting electrode films shown excellent performance that is nearly independent of film thickness up to 200 micrometers [212]. In 2019, porous MXene/conducting polymer hybrid materials for flexible alternating current (AC) filtering electrochemical capacitors. Reproduced with permission [213]. Copyright 2019, Elsevier. In addition, 3D structured hydrogel from 2D MXene sheets was prepared by new gelation method. Reproduced with permission [214]. Copyright 2019, WILEY-VCH. In 2020, 3D-printed sodium-ion hybrid capacitor based on nitrogen-doped MXene (N-Ti3C2T x ) anode and activated carbon cathode achieved a gravimetric energy/power density of 101.6 Wh kg−1/3269 W kg−1. Reproduced with permission [215]. Copyright 2020, American Chemical Society. Fig. 3 An overview of the synthetic pathways and energy storage applications of 2D MXene-based heterostructures. Here, the synthetic pathways include hydrothermal, electrostatic self-assembly, and high temperature in-situ derivation. The energy storage applications contain supercapacitor (SC), Li-ion battery (LIB), Na-ion battery (SIB), K-ion battery (PIB), multivalent metal ion battery (MMIB, such as Mg, Al and Zn ion battery), and metal anode protection. Graphic abstract This review comprehensively summarizes and discusses the recent progress on the MXene heterostructures materials in terms of synthesis strategies, morphology engineering, physical/chemical properties, and their applications in energy storage. The challenges and opportunities in this field are systematically analyzed and prospected. This work will provide valuable references for achieving the high-efficiency energy storage in the near future. MXenes are a family of two-dimensional (2D) transition metal carbides, carbonitrides/nitrides with superior physical and chemical properties, which have attracted extensive attention since the discovery in 2011. The impressive electrochemical activity of MXene makes it one of the most potential electrode materials in rechargeable batteries and supercapacitors. However, single-component MXene electrodes are difficult to achieve high specific capacity, efficient ion/electron transport, and high stability compatibility in an electrochemical environment. Studies have shown that it is an effective method to introduce nanomaterials between MXene layers to construct heterostructures and to improve the electrochemical performance through the synergistic effect among the components in the heterostructures. The introduction of nanomaterials can effectively suppress the restacking of MXene nanosheets, shorten the diffusion path of ions and promote the electrolyte transport, which is beneficial to enhance the rate performance of MXene; moreover, the excellent mechanical flexibility of MXene can reduce the volume expansion of nanomaterials during charge/discharge, thereby effectively protecting the integrity of the electrode structure and improving the cycling stability. Therefore, in this review, combined with theoretical calculations, we summarize the recent advances of MXene heterostructures in terms of synthesis strategies and energy storage applications, including supercapacitors, metal-ions batteries (Li, Na, K, Mg, Zn, Al) and metal anode protection. Furthermore, potential challenges and application perspectives for MXene heterostructures are also outlined. Keywords MXene heterostructures Construction techniques Energy storage 1 Introduction MXenes are a family of transition metal carbides, carbonitrides and nitrides with two-dimensional (2D) srtucture, which attract the research attentation around the world due to the large specific surface area, high conductivity, and abundant surface functional groups [1,2]. MXenes with a chemical formula M n +1X n T x (where n = 1 ~ 3, M is an early transition metal, X denotes carbon and/or nitrogen and T x represents the surface terminations, OH/O/F) are prepared by the selective etching of the A layers (mostly group IIIA or IVA elements) from the MAX phases (Fig. 1 a). Compared with the most common 2D materials such as graphene, MXene has the following advantages: (i) good hydrophilicity. MXene with high conductivity can be stably dispersed in water to form a colloidal suspension; (ii) diverse layer structure: monolayer and multi-layer accordion structure. Among them, the interlayer spacing of the multilayer structure is about 1 ~ 2 nm, which are beneficial for adsorbing large amounts of electrolyte ions. (iii) rich structure and chemical composition. There are more than 70 kinds of MAX phases in the precursor of MXene so far, by adjusting the M element or changing the value of n in the chemical formula of M n +1AX n , MXene containing different transition metals or different thickness and stability can be obtained. (iiii) various surface functional groups, which is a highly polar surface; and the different functional groups have a great influence on the physical and chemical properties of MXene. Based on the above advantages, MXene has received great attention in the fields of energy storage [3–9], catalysis [10,11], sensors [12–15], adsorption [16,17], hydrogen storage [18,19], electromagnetic interference shielding [20–22], and so on [23,24]. However, it is noted that the surface of the MXene nanolayer has high surface energy and always terminated by functional groups, which result in a decline in the electrochemical properties of MXenes, and the nanosheets of MXene attract each other, reducing the interlayer gap, which is the channals for ionic diffusion transmission. Therefore, the reported ions storage performance of pure MXene is significantly lower than that theoretical performance. Although MXenes are a relatively young 2D materials, the related research on MXenes is increasing year by year (Figs. 1b and 2 ). In particular, many scholars use MXene as a substrate, and combine zero-dimensional (0D) ~ 2D materials with MXene nanosheets to form MXene heterostructures, which belong to heterogeneous composite materials. Then benefit from the synergistic effect between the components in the heterostructure to improve the energy storage performance in recent years [25–28]. For example, graphene wrapped MXene 2D materials (MXene@rGO) are successfully prepared by Wang et al. and used in all solid-state flexible supercapacitors [29]. Comparing to regular MXene, the MXene@rGO exhibited twice higher specific capacitance. Zhou et al. mainly studied the potassium stroage performance of N-doped graphene (NG)/ReSe2/MXene heterostructure, this material has excellent structural stability, which can afford facile K+ diffusion, enhance overall conductivity and boost high-power performance. As anode for potassium-ion battery (PIB), an outstanding reversible capacity (90 mAh g−1, 5 A g−1) after 300 cycles was obtained [30]. Thanks to the increase of Ti3C2 interlayer spacing and the dissolution/diffusion of Se, Ti3C2@CTAB (hexadecyl trimethyl ammonium Bromide)-Se composite exhibits excellent electrochemical performance for rechargeable aluminum batteries [31]. These studies suggest that constructing MXene heterostructures to improve energy storage performance is an extremely effective technology (Tables 1–3 ). In order to better understand the development potential of MXene heterostructure materials in the field of energy storage, it is highly desirable to summarize this aspect. However, at present, the existing review may focus on the preparation of MXene or summarize its application in a specific field (such as synthesis and properties [32], capacitors [33–36], lithium or non-lithium batteries [4,37–39], environmental-related applications [40,41]). Therefore, it is necessary to classify the preparation methods and applications of MXene heterostructures, as depicted in Fig. 3 . In the following sections, we outline the latest developments in MXene heterostructures, covering both theoretical and experimental studies. After that, we describle the challenges and future research prospects in the MXene field to facilitate more explorations of the promising and rapidly expanding series of this materials. 2 Theoretical calculation Recently, many researchers have used first-principles to theoretically predict the properties of MXene and MXene-based materials in multiple areas [42–46], which provide theoretical guide for experiments. For electrode performance of MXenes, the structural stability and electronic properties of MXenes (Ti3C2, V2C) were systematically investigated, then the excellent characteristics as Li ion-battery (LIB) anodes were predicted through density functional theory (DFT) computations [44]. The Li storage capacity was highly dependent on the surface functional groups [47]. The calculation for Li diffusion on V2CO2 surface indicates the Li mobility on V2CO2 is larger than on V2CF2 and V2C(OH)2 [48]. Moreover, the Li storage capacity of V2CO2Li4 was up to 735 mAh g−1, as shown in Fig. 4 a [45]. In particular, owing to the low diffusion barrier and high storage capacity for metal ions (Li, Na, K and Ca), V3C2 MXene is predicted to be a promising anode material especially for LIBs and sodium ion batteries (SIBs) [43]. Furthermore, as depicted in Fig. 4b, first-principles simulation was used to understand the storage mechanism of metal ions (Na+, K+, Mg2+, Ca2+ and Al3+) when MXene was used as the electrode of non-lithium ion batteries [49]. Compared with separate transition-metal dichalcogenides (TMDs) (including MoS2, WS2, MoSe2, and WSe2) and Sc2CF2 monolayers, the heterostructure TMD-Sc2CF2 bilayers can be tuned to indirect semiconductors (Fig. 4c) [50]. Moreover, different from pure MoS2, the calculation results indicated that 2D MoS2-on-MXene heterostructures (MoS2/Mo2TiC2O2) possessed a stronger adsorption for Li and lower binding energies (Fig. 4d) [26], and the oxygen surface in the MoS2/Mo2TiC2O2 interface also shown electrons accumulation, suggesting stronger charge transfer (Fig. 4e). Jiang et al. analyzed the sodium storage mechanism of MoSe2/MXene heterojunction as anodes for SIBs by DFT calculations. As displayed in Fig. 4f and g, when MoSe2 is combined with MXene, MXene occupies the unoccupied conduction band of MoSe2 and drops to the Fermi level, thus the entire heterojunction system exhibited metallic characteristics, indicating that there is electronic transport between MoSe2 and MXene [51]. DFT results suggested that the black phosphorus (BP)/Ti3C2 composite possessed a broader conduction band and a valence band compared with BP and Ti3C2 [52], the average interval between BP and the Ti3C2 nanoflake was calculated to be about 0.17 nm, providing enough space for the storage and transfer of Na+ and resulting in the impressive electrochemical performance in SIBs. Wang groups investigated the adsorption behavior of Na on the Ti3C2T x , BP, and their hybrid, respectively [28]. As depicted in Fig. 4h, the calculation results demonstrated that the adsorption and intercalation of Na atoms in the phosphorene/MXene hybrid have been significantly enhanced, and the diffusion energy barrier of Na in BP/Ti3C2F2 is much lower than that in BP/Ti3C2(OH)2, therefore, the corresponding diffusion rate is also faster. Similarly, Wu et al. reported that the on the black phosphorene (BPE)@V2CF2 structure had a stronger adsorption for K than that of BPE@V2C(OH)2, indicating that the existence of the F functional group in the heterojunction electrode is beneficial to the K storage [53]. In addition, Du et al. systematically studied the Li adsorption properties of prototypical MXene/graphene (G) heterostructures for potential applications as electrodes in LIBs [25]. The DFT energetics clearly demonstrated a stronger interaction energy between MnO2 and MXene of −0.597 eV than the MnO2-rGO interaction energy of −0.181 eV. And the obtained result obviously predicted a stronger interfacial electronic coupling of manganese oxide with MXene than with rGO, strongly suggesting remarkable merit of MXene nanosheet as a hybridization matrix [54]. Based on DFT and by comparing the adsorption energy of K atoms on each component, Xia et al. better corroborated the essence of excellent K+ storage performance of N-doped graphene (NG)/ReSe2/Ti3C2 heterostructure [30]. As shown in Fig. 4i. Therefore, the presence of graphene not only avoids restacking effects of MXene layers but also enhances the electric conductivity, metal ions adsorption strength, and mechanical stiffness. According to the theoretical calculation results, 2D nanomaterials are compounded with other materials at the nanoscale to construct a heterostructure, which contains a large number of well-contacted heterogeneous interfaces, exhibiting different physical and chemical properties from the matrix. 3 Experimental synthesis From the prediction of theoretical calculation, building MXene heterostructures is a way to optimize the performance of MXene electrode materials. Currently, there are three common synthesis methods for constructing MXene heterostructures: i) hydrothermal method, ii) electrostatic self-assembly method, and iii) high temperature in-situ derivation method. 3.1 Hydrothermal method The hydrothermal method refers to a method in which MXene and the second phase dispersed in the liquid phase prepare a heterostructure under hydrothermal conditions. This method can improve the activity of materials and change the surface functional groups of MXene under high temperature and high pressure. In 2017, Qiao et al. prepared a Ti3C2/CdS heterostructure by hydrothermal treatment and the heterostructure exhibited both super high visible-light photocatalytic activity and apparent quantum efficiency [55]. Cao et al. made the heterostructure of Ti3C2/Bi2WO6 using hydrothermal strategy by the growth of Bi2WO6 on the surface of Ti3C2 (Fig. 5 a–c) [56]. This heterostructure had a large interfacial contact area and extremely short charge transfer distance, which can significantly improve the photocatalytic efficiency. Subsequently, MoSe2/Ti3C2 heterojunctions as ultrafast kinetics net electrode were assembled through hydrothermal followed by thermal annealing (Fig. 5d) [51], the MoSe2/Ti3C2 heterojunctions presented a 3D network with loose and rich porous structure, which was conductive to the penetration of electrolyte the transmission of electrons during the reaction. It exhibited a reversible capacity of 434 mAh g−1 at 1 A g−1 for 200 cycles as a potential anode. Oxides are generated in situ during the hydrothermal process, as described in Fig. 5e, TiO2 was generated during the preparation of Ti3C2T x MXene decorated BP nanosheet heterojunction [57]. Furthermore, as for the TEM images of Ti3C2T x /TiO2-BP, obviously, a regular oval Ti3C2T x /TiO2 was formed on the surface of BP sheets and this “face-to-face” contact could promote the electron transfer from BP to Ti3C2T x (Fig. 5f and g). Apart from Ti3C2 MXene, other MXene-based heterostructures can also synthesized by this method. For instance, the 3D mesh heterostructure paramontroseite-VO2 nanorod clusters grown on the V2C MXene nanosheets shown ultra-high electrochemical performance [58]. In the 2D heterogeneous vanadium compound VS2/V2C, VS2 nanosheets were grown vertically and uniformly on the V2C MXene surface in the hydrothermal process, as depicted in Fig. 5h–j [46]. There are advantages of fast charge transfer speed and good conductivity at the two-phase interface, which made VS2/V2C show low Tafel slope and hydrogen evolution overpotential in the high alkali/acid electrolyte. 3.2 Electrostatic self-assembly method Electrostatic self-assembly is a common method to construct 2D heterostructures, which is achieved by the mutual attraction of heterogeneous nanocells with different surface charges. Using this method, a variety of MXene heterostructure materials have been prepared and applied in many fields. For example, free-standing and aligned tungstate/MXene fibers were achieved by electrostatic interactions and applied for flexible LIBs and SIBs [59]. The highly conductive MXene@polystyrene (PS) nanocomposite was made by electrostatically assembling negative Ti3C2T x nanosheets on positive PS microspheres and then compression molding [20], as shown in Fig. 6 a. The resultant nanocomposites with superb conductivity exhibited an outstanding electromagnetic interference (EMI) shielding performance. Driven by electrostatic interaction, the delaminated Ti3C2T x /CoAl layered double hydroxide (Ti3C2T x /CoAl-LDH) heterogeneous were synthesized [60,61]. As the cathode of alkaline hybrid battery, the electrochemical activity of Ti3C2T x /CoAl-LDH heterogeneous electrode and the kinetics of Faraday reaction could effectively improve. Similarly, the freestanding MXene/NiCo-LDHs electrode could obtained by the same method with a regular interstratification structure and large interlayer spacing [62,63], this material possessed excellent electrochemical performance when used in supercapacitors and LIBs. Some metal oxides and MXene can also be combined by electrostatic self-assembly. The positively charged MnO2 nanosheets (MNSs) modified by CTAB were combined with the negatively charged d-Ti3C2 MXene (Fig. 6b) [64]. The resulting 3D MNSs@d-Ti3C2 aerogel framework had a mesoporous structure and high specific surface area that were conducive to high sulfur loading, the MNSs@d-Ti3C2/S cathode containing 3.7 mg cm−2 sulfur loading delivered an outstanding initial discharge capacity (1140 mAh g−1) and stable cycle performance (500 cycles) at 1.0 C for Li−S battery. Zhuang et al. constructed a novel 1D/2D photocatalyst of TiO2 nanofibers (TiO2 NFs)/Ti3C2 nanocomposites [65], due to the strong interfacial contact between TiO2 NFs and Ti3C2 nanosheets, photogenerated carriers were effectively separated, thereby enhancing the photocatalytic activity. Chen and co-workers synthesized different dimensional SnO2 quantum dots (QDs)/MXene composites [66]. MXene played a role in buffering the volume change of SnO2 during charging/discharging, while the SnO2 QDs applies as “spacers” to open the layer spacing of MXene nanosheets. When applied as anode for LIBs, SnO2 QDs/MXene delivered impressive capacity and rate performance, as shown in Fig. 6c–d. Furthermore, a Bi2MoO6/Ti3C2T x heterostructures were reported by Xu’s group [67]. In this heterostructure, the high-conductivity Ti3C2T x was used as the substrate to load and anchor the Bi2MoO6 nanoplates to realize the improvement of electronic conductivity and structural stability (Fig. 6e). Zhao et al. reasonably designed a molecular-level PDDA-BP/Ti3C2 (PDDA = poly (diallyl dimethyl ammoniumchloride)) heterostructure [68], the modification of cationic polymer PDDA on layered BP not only improves electronegativity of BP nanosheets, but also passivates them to prevent from oxidization in water. Furthermore, the cationic Fe-N-C nanosheets were assembled with anionic MXene sheets driven by the electrostatic forces, which generate the corresponding 2D/2D superlattice-like heterostructure [10]. The resultant Fe-N-C/MXene has indicated good electrocatalytic performance toward the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) process characteristic. In addition, the CTAB modified 3D sisal-like NiCo2S4 wrapped by 2D MXene was also prepared by electrostatic self-assembly, as described in Fig. 6f–h [69]. The optimized NiCo2S4/MXene heterojunction possessed wonderful electrochemical performance with high specific capacity and capacity retention of 94.27% after 5000 cycles. Moreover, the assembled pouch-cell type device displayed a high energy density (68.7 Wh kg−1, 0.85 kW kg−1). 3.3 High temperature in-situ derivation method High-temperature in-situ derivation is the method to form a second phase on the surface of MXenes by heat treating MXene with/without other phases. During the heat treatment, oxidation, sulfidation or phase transformation happens and MXene heterostructures are constructed. Ti3C2 is a relatively mature MXene phase, through in-situ derivation technology, a variety of MXene-derived heterostructure materials are synthesized. For instance, the TiO2 nanocrystals generated by heating 2D Ti3C2 in air were trapped in the disordered graphitic carbon structure and had a very high cycle rate when employed as anodes for LIBs (Fig. 7 a) [70]. Li et al. reported a heterojunction material of TiO2 nanowires grown in situ on Ti3C2 MXene using alkali oxidation, the urchin-like Ti3C2/TiO2 composite demonstrated a record high sensitivity in a low relative humidity (RH) environment [71]. As a data-storage medium in memory devices, a series of MXene-TiO2 core–shell nanosheets were also obtained by deterministic control of the surface oxidation of MXene [72]. Moreover, using Ti3C2 MXene as the carbon skeleton and homologous titanium source, through electrostatic interaction and in-situ conversion in CO2 atmosphere at 550 °C to produce the 2D layered N-doped carbon-supported titanium dioxides (N-TiO2@C), as shown in Fig. 7b [73]. The obtained N-TiO2@C composites displayed the high efficiency of phenol degradation. Similarly, a series of carbon-doped TiO2 modified g-C3N4 (C-TiO2/g-C3N4) photocatalysts were prepared by calcining a mixture of Ti3C2 and bulk g-C3N4 [11]. The mixture of Ti3C2 and urea was directly calcinated to obtain ultra-thin 2D/2D Ti3C2/g-C3N4 heterojunction, the role of urea was not only as a gas template for stripping Ti3C2, but also as a source of material for obtaining g-C3N4 (Fig. 7c) [74]. In addition, some nanorods or nanobelts could also be derived from MXene. Using the one-step scalable conversion reaction, a new sandwich-like 1D Na0.23TiO2 nanobelts/2D Ti3C2 nanosheets composite was obtained (Fig. 7d) [75]. This material combines the advantages of 1D nanobelt, 2D nanosheet and 3D network structure, and realizes the interface of internal electrical connection, indicating that it becomes a potential candidate for excellent performance rechargeable battery electrode material. The NaV6O15 nanorods, prepared by a low temperature thermal oxidization of Na-intercalated V2CT x , spontaneously grew in the interlayers and directly damaged the layered structure of MXene [76]. As anode for LIBs, the NaV6O15 hybrid delivered a predominant capacity and maintained 100% Coulombic efficiency after 200 cycles at 1 A g−1. In view of the many advantages of MXene, Wu et al. proved for the first time that MXene can be used as a metal source for the synthesis of a novel type of metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) with a 2D nanosheet morphology, as described in Fig. 7e [77], a facile solvothermal method was employed to convert the V2CT x MXene and H2TCPP (meso-tetra(4-carboxyl-phenyl) porphyrin) into V-PMOF. Combined with the excellent uniformity of MOF film, the resulting V2CT x -PMOF exhibits striking proton conductivity under acid immersion, which is promising for applications in electronics, sensing and electrochemistry. Subsequently, Zhao et al. calcined the CoMo LDH@MXene heterostructure obtained by electrostatic self-assembly in a N2 atmosphere at 350 °C for 2 h, and finally obtained transition metal oxides (TMOs)@MXene (CoO/Co2Mo3O8@MXene) hollow frameworks (Fig. 7f–h) [78], the formed hollow polyhedron material combines the excellent electrical conductivity and mechanical robustness of MXene, as well as the remarkable storage performance of CoO/Co2Mo3O8 nanosheets. Among the above three common synthesis methods, the advantage of hydrothermal method is to prepare some difficult to synthesize heterostructure systems by improving and increasing the activity of reactants. The advantage of electrostatic self-assembly method is that the technology is relatively mature, but the surface of the constituent materials needs to be pretreated. The advantage of the in-situ derivation method is that the second phase is more firmly combined with MXene, but the second phase has a smaller choice of space, and it is mostly related to the MXene matrix composition, and the derived second phase is mostly 0D or 1D materials. Overall, these above MXene-based heterostructures offer efficient electron and ion transport at the interface. Parallel two-dimensional interlayer voids offer effective charge transfer and ion diffusion channels. And effectively alleviates volume expansion/agglomeration during charging/discharging. As energy storage materials, they all have more excellent comprehensive performance than the pure MXene. For the synthesis of MXene heterojunction, this section mainly summarized three simple and commonly used methods. Furthermore, a stable Ti-O-X bond is formed between the interface of MXene and the active material by ball-milling and ultrasound to construct a MXene heterostructure [79,80]. Here, the existence of the Ti-O-X bond is beneficial for achieving effective interface charge transfer and high interface mechanical stability; moreover, it can polarize the atomic charge in the heterostructure, thereby enhancing the storage of pseudocapacitive and ensuring the extraordinary comprehensive performance of battery [81]. In addition, the researchers used vacuum filtration and atomic layer deposition (ALD) methods to synthesize MXene heterostructures [82–84]. Thanks to the sheet shape of MXene, the resulting material exhibits the sandwich structure, which is beneficial to alleviate the stacking of MXene and the volume expansion of the active material, thereby improving the cycle stability of the battery. Through in-situ partial oxidation technology [85–87], the surface functional groups of MXene can be fully utilized, and the metal oxides produced can help improve the overall performance of the MXene heterostructure. 4 Energy storage applications Based on theoretical predictions and experimental design, combined with the advantages of the MXene nanosheets (such as excellent electronic conductivity, good structural stability, hydrophilicity and mechanical properties), the MXene-based heterostructure is widely used in the field of electrochemical energy storage, including applications in supercapacitors, metal (Li, Na, K, Mg, Zn, Al) batteries and metal anode protection. 4.1 Supercapacitors Supercapacitor (SC), as an energy storage device, can store charge by adsorption of electrolyte ions on the electrode materials surface or by pseudocapacitive faradaic reactions. MXenes with multifarious functional groups have unique electronic properties proved by theoretical calculation [33]. Studies have shown that MXenes are suitable for electrode materials due to their 2D structure, which improves the mechanical stability and shortens the ion diffusion paths between the positive and negative electrodes [88]. Therefore, MXenes are expected to be a promising candidate electrode in SC. However, the facile stacking of MXene nanosheets result in decreasing the electrical conductivity and the contact area between electrolyte and electrode, which have a significant limitation of capacitance. Although expansile interlayer spacing achieved by delaminating can effectively increase the active sites with the enhancement of the electrochemical performance [89,90], the inevitable restacking of MXene flakes can still restrict the capacitive performance. The introduction of interlayer spacer and the heterostructures formed by MXene and multiple nano-materials can effectively improve the capacitance electrochemical behavior [82,83,91,92]. LDHs exhibit high redox activity/specific capacity, and low cost as electrode material in alkaline electrolytes [93–95]. It is reasonable that heterostructures formed by MXenes and LDHs can further improve the properties of capacitance [96–98]. For instance, the introduced Ti3C2 MXene atomic layers much enhances the intrinsic performance of NiCo-LDHs, forming the 3D irregular honeycomb-like sandwich-type composite, this composite possesses ultrahigh rate capability and long-life stability in battery-type supercapacitors [99]. A high capacitance of Ti3C2/Ni-Co-Al-LDH heterostructures was up to 748.2 F g−1 [100]. The homogeneous growth of Ni-Al-LDH on the surface of exfoliated Ti3C2 MXene fabricated by in situ method also shows an excellent capacitance [96]. This MXene/LDH composite has a 3D porous structure, a conductive network formed by MXene frame facilitates the electron transport of active material. The optimal weight percentage of MXene in M30/LDH displays super specific capacitance. V4C3 MXene also successfully formed a heterostructure with LDHs and shown 627 C g−1 at 1 A g−1 in 1 M KOH [27]. In particular, hybrid supercapacitors equipped with V4C3/Ni-Co-Al-LDH heterostructures and activated carbon displayed 71.7 Wh kg−1 in 1 M KOH. In the flexible and wearable SC, the composite of MXene and carbon-based materials has the ability to improve the capacity of MXene-based electrodes. Especially, the graphene can signally improve supercapacitive performance impeding the aggregations of individual graphene flake due to the introduction of the carbon nanotube (CNT) [101,102]. Compared with 1D or 2D nanomaterials, the sandwich-like morphology fabricated by layer-by-layer assembly processes is beneficial to exhibit better electrochemical performances [103,104]. A sandwich-like Ti3C2/CNTs composite papers with free-standing and highly flexible achieved by alternating filtration is employed as electrode materials in supercapacitors. As an electrode, 390 F cm−3 volumetric capacitance for MXene/CNT composites was observed at 2 mV s−1 and even no degradation of holding 350 F cm−3 after 10,000 cycles could be measured [105]. A kind of reduced graphene oxide (rGO) combined with Ti3C2 was made to bridge electrochemically active conducting particles and applied to manufacture flexible all-solid-state supercapacitors in 2017 [106]. The conductive frame formed by rGO can improve the conductivity between Ti3C2 layers and Ti3C2 particles due to the tight connection of them, moreover, the Ti3C2 particles weaken the agglomeration of rGO nanoflakes and increase the ions transport [107]. Based on this special structure, an excellent energy conversion/storage device was assembled by rGO/Ti3C2 film, which exhibited high volumetric capacitance of 370 F cm−3 at 1 A g−1 with KOH electrolyte. In addition, The rGO/MXene hybrid electrode film fabricated by electrostatic self-assembly possessed a high conductivity (2261 S cm−1) and volume capacitance (1040 F cm−3) [108], as shown in Fig. 8 a and b. When the loading of MXene was only 5 wt%, the volume capacity value of the hybrid electrode at 0.1 A g−1 could reach 345.2 F cm−3 (Fig. 8c and d) [109]. The presence of holey graphene could form a better conductive network structure, and also had a good alleviation effect on the restacking of MXene nanosheets, as depicted in Fig. 8e–g, the Ti3C2/holey graphene has been applied to supercapacitor, a superb volumetric capacitance and an outstanding volumetric energy density were achieved [110]. In addition, polymerization of pyrrole (PPy) as a conductive polymer can not only expand the space of MXene to intercalate between the MXene layers, but also construct aligned paths for electrical transport, as shown in Fig. 8h [111]. The XRD and TEM results showed that the PPy intercalated the Ti3C2 layers and the polymer chains are highly aligned. A volumetric capacitance and a capacitance retention of 92% after 25,000 cycles were observed (Fig. 8i). Similarly, Ti3C2/polyaniline hybrid material was obtained by in-situ polymerization of polyaniline without oxidant agent [112]. The corresponding electrodes delivered an exceptional gravimetric and volumetric capacitance of ~ 503 F g−1 and 1682 F cm−3, respectively, moreover, the hybrid electrodes can hold high electrochemical performance with the increasing of the electrode thicknesses and mass loadings. A combination of polyfluorene derivatives (PFDs), a kind of synthetic conjugated polymer, and Ti3C2 was synthesized [113]. As displayed in Fig. 8j–l, the volumetric capacitance of the PFDs/Ti3C2 is 1026 F cm−3 at 2 mV s−1, and this hybrid can effectively solve the typical problem that polymer-based electrodes have poor cyclic ability and short lifetime. In recent years, introducing TMO can impede the re-stacking of MXenes, which in turn can increase the conductivity of TMO, thereby increasing capacitance storage. For example, the TiO2/Ti3C2 compounds showed 1.5 times higher capacitance than pure Ti3C2 at 5 mV s−1 [114], an impressive cycling stability with 92% initial capacitance retention after 6000 cycles in 6 M KOH aqueous electrolyte was also observed in this research. Benefiting from the 2D morphology of two compounds stacked alternately, Liu et al. seek MnO2 with high theoretical capacitance and natural abundance coupled with Ti3C2 sheets to fabricate a flexible film supercapacitor [115]. Furthermore, most of the active metal ions in 2D MnO2 sheets are accessible to the electrolyte. A superb electrochemical performance is delivered in a highly reversible and symmetric two-electrode prototype supercapacitor. WO3/MXene composite shown a higher specific capacitance (297 F g−1) compared with pure WO3 (121 F g−1) at 1 A g−1 in H2SO4 aqueous electrolyte [116]. Additionally, the flexible all-solid-state supercapacitor made of V2O5/Ti3C2 hybrid electrode had a superior areal capacitance and an excellent active mass loading [117], and such a novel device can exhibit stable performance at different bending states, which is more conducive to the wearable equipment. Based on the remarkable improvement of capacitance caused by the combination between TMOs and MXenes, it can be seen that the MXenes act as electrons collector effectively improving the electrical conductivity and offering more electrons to participate redox reaction with transition metal oxide happened on the surface of electrodes. Besides, some transition metal oxides display multiple oxidation state. Hence, there is no doubt that the MXene with low-cost TMO is hopeful used for commercial application. 4.2 Li-based battery 4.2.1 Li-ion batteries The metallic or narrow band gap semiconductor characteristic of MXenes, weak interlayer force and high specific surface area make it a potential candidate for for LIBs anode material. However, owing to the electrostatic interaction force between the MXene layers, the sheets are easy to restack, resulting in a serious degradation in conductivity and surface area. The pre-intercalation of alkali metal ions is also an effective way to enhance Li storage capacity. Compared with Na+ and Mg2+, high-valence cation Al3+ into MXenes layer as “Tents-Pitching” affords a strong Coulombic interaction upon lithiation/charging process to sustain ion transport channels [118]. Moreover, lower F surface termination are beneficial to increasing electron conductivity and then enhancing Li storage performance [119,120]. Compared with the use of alkali metal ions to increase the lithium storage capacity, the carbon nanofibers (CNFs) growing on the MXene layers surface have a certain effect on preventing the restacking of MXene layers (Fig. 9 a) [121]. The Ti3C2/CNF composites possessed larger interlayer spacing than the bare Ti3C2 and displayed improved capacities, therefore, the heterojunction shown superior long-term cycling and brilliant rate performance. Moreover, thanks to the conductive network and buffering effect of Ti3C2T x /CNTs, and the stable Ti-O-P bonds, a wonderful reversible capacity (2598 mAh g−1, 0.05C), an outstanding cycling stability (2078 mAh g−1 after 500 cycles) and exceptional rate capability (454 mAh g−1, 30C) were obtained in Ti3C2T x /CNTs@P materials (Fig. 9b, c) [79]. Furthermore, by mixing rGO with MXenes, the resulting composite material exhibited excellent Li storage performance [122]. Sn and Ag nanoparticales were introduced and combined with Ti3C2T x MXene to improve the electrochemical performance [123,124]. The as-prepared polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP)-Sn(IV)@Ti3C2 and MXene/Ag composites have two advantages: (i) the Ti3C2T x layers interlayer spacing was increased by Sn and Ag spacers, (ii) the presence of metal particles Sn and Ag could improve the conductivity of the composite material. Wang et al. engineered the V2C@Co composite by ion-exchange interaction and electrostatic interactions, Co ions could be stably embedded in the interlayer of V2C MXene to form a strong V-O-Co bonding [125]. For Li-ion storage the V2C@Co electrodes achieved a superior capability up to 1117.3 mAh g−1 at 0.1 A g−1 and delivered a signifcantly long cycling stability over 15,000 cycles with almost no capacity loss. In view of the possibility of synergistic optimization between MXene and TMO, many researchers have recombined 2D MXene with good electronic conductivity and TMO with high capacity. In 2016, Nb2O5@Nb4C3T x (or @Nb2CT x ) and TiO2@Ti3C2T x hierarchical composites were synthesized, as displayed in Fig. 9d [85]. These composites possessed better Li storage performance, which become ascribed to the synergy between the components and the electronic “bridge” effect of disordered carbon. In previous reports, SnO2 nanoparticles and MXene composite materials were obtained by ALD technique or hydrothermal method [84,126]. Recently, TiO2 nanorods and SnO2 nanowires could be self-assembled on MXene (Ti3C2) nanosheets through the interaction of van der Waals forces (Fig. 9e) [127]. And these two kinds heterostructures (TiO2/MXene, SnO2/MXene) shown excellent rate capacities, respectively (Fig. 9f, g). Wang et al. presented a self-standing hybrid film of SnO2 nanotube/MXene was fabricated by alternate vacuum filtration, this intelligent design resolves the issues of low conductivity and serious volume expansion of SnO2 at the same time [128]. As anodes for LIBs, a reversible capacity of 663 mAh g−1 after 100 cycles at 100 mA g−1 and an excellent rate capability with a reversible capacity of 327 mAh g−1 at 5 A g−1 were exhibited. Furthermore, the study found that the charge polarization caused by the Ti–O–Fe covalent bond can greatly accelerate the kinetics and electron transfer of the lithiation reaction, thus, Fe3O4@Ti3C2 and Ti3C2T x /Fe2O3 hybrid nanocomposites as anodes for LIBs were prepared [129–131]. The Fe3O4 and Fe2O3 nanocrystals were well-anchored between MXene interlayers with abundant active sites exposure for each component. In order to alleviate the volume expansion of Si, SiO, and SiO2 anodes during cycling, MXene&Si [132], Ti3C2T x -CNT/SiNPs (Si nanoparticles) [133], MXene/Si@SiO x @C [134], Si/Ti3C2 [135,136], microsphere-like SiO2/MXene [137], and Si p-NS@TNSs [138], SiO/wrinkled MXene [139] composites were synthesized. Among them, the layered superstructure MXene/Si@SiO x @C has wonderful Li storage performance (as shown in Fig. 9h and i), which is attributed to the autoadjustable function of the MXene layer spacing, that is, during the discharging process, the lithiation of Si-based active material led to an increase of the interlayer spacing; while in the charge process, the material delithiation caused the interlayer spacing to decrease. On the whole, the MXene layer played a role of buffering and protection [134]. In addition, Li3VO4 (LVO)/Ti3C2T x MXene composite had an excellent Li storage performance (146 mAh g−1 after 1000 cycles) [140]. The symmetric lithium full cells with the highest energy density of 393.4 Wh kg−1 was developed by Peng’s group based on the bipolar material MXene/Na0.55Mn1.4Ti0.6O4 [141]. Moreover, to address the issues of the poor Li storage performance due to the agglomeration of CoFe2O4 nanoparticles (NPs), Ti3C2T x MXene was employed as a substrate to crosslink CoFe2O4 NPs (Fig. 9j, k) [142]. The resulting heterojunction exhibited 676 mAh g−1 reversible capacity and stable cycling behaviour for 940 cycles. Additionally, the layered MXenes could act as a conductive substrate for nanosized CoO particles and improve the electron transfer rate, the formed CoO/Ti3C2T x heterojunction was applied for Li-O2 battery [143]. The various heterostructures constructed by transition metal dichalcogenides (MoS2, SnS2, FeS2, and Fe7S8) and MXenes were considered to be an excellent Li storage anode material [26,144–146]. For example, The as-prepared 2D MoS2-on-MXene heterostructures synthesized via in-situ sulfidation of Mo2TiC2T x MXene exhibited promising rate capability and excellent cycling stability [26]. Similarly, Bai et al. constructed the novel V4C3-MXene/MoS2/C nanohybrids via hydrothermal method (Fig. 9l) [147]. Benefiting from the advantages of large interlayer of composite materials, short Li-ion diffusion distance, fast reaction kinetics, high electrical conductivity and strong structural stability, the hierarchical nanohybrid electrode shown an excellent cycling stability after 450 cycles and a superior rate capability (500 mAh g−1, 10 A g−1) (Fig. 9m, n). SnS2/Sn3S4 hybrid decorated on Ti3C2 MXene (S-TC) was prepared and acted as anode material for LIBs [144], S-TC demonstrated a superior high-rate capability and great cycling life due to the synergetic effects between the multi-layered Ti3C2 and SnS2/Sn3S4 hybrid nanoparticles. In addition, through the in-situ polymerization of pyrrole monomer and alkalized Ti3C2T x , followed by vulcanization at 700 °C, 3D TiO2@N-doped carbon (NC)/Fe7S8 composite was finally fabricated, which demonstrated a robust long cycling stability of 282 mAh g−1 after 1000 cycles at 4 A g−1 [146]. 4.2.2 Li−S batteries Lithium−sulfur (Li−S) batteries with high theoretical specific capacity (~1680 mAh g−1) are regarded as one of high-performance rechargeable battery systems following LIBs [148]. Unfortunately, in actual experiments, the performance of Li−S batteries is restricted by the poor conductivity and large volume expansion of sulfur, and the shuttle of polysulfide. Among them, the suppression of the polysulfde shuttle effect is the main challenge that has hindered the development of Li–S batteries. In order to solve these problems, in view of the outstanding electrical conductivity and abundant surface functional groups of 2D MXenes, when employed as a cathode substrate, it had a certain adsorption effect on strong S/polysulfide [39,149,150]. Wu and co-workers employed 3D alkalized Ti3C2 MXene (a-Ti3C2 MNR) as a S/polysulfides host (a-Ti3C2-S) and 2D d-Ti3C2 nanosheets as interlayer on the polypropylene (PP) separator for high-energy–density Li−S batteries [151]. The doping heteroatomic N into the Ti3C2T x MXene nanosheets also contributed to improve the affinity and the binding energy of polar Ti atoms with elemental S and polar polysulfides [152], as displayed in Fig. 10 a. Thus, the as-prepared crumpled N-doped Ti3C2T x MXene/sulfur (N-Ti3C2T x /S) composites had the capability of physical and chemical dual-adsorption for polysulfides, achieved a high S loading and an extended cycling stability (Fig. 10b, c). Further introducing CNT to obtain N-Ti3C2@CNT microsphere/S composite cathode [153], thereby promoting electron transport and enhancing the electrochemical reaction kinetics. Moreover, A large number of positively charged S vacancy defects generated on MXene/1T-2H MoS2-C could prevent the dissolution of polysulfides [154]. Gao et al. confirmed the TiO2 QDs@MXene nanohybrids could be applied as sulfur host [155]. Notably, S could also be tightly adhered on the surface of Ti3C2T x nanodots-interspersed Ti3C2T x nanosheet (TCD-TCS), forming a closely packed structure [156], and the S loading of this material is as high as 13.8 mg cm−2. In recent years, as described in Fig. 10d and e, Tang et al. reported on a robust, conductive Ti3C2T x /S paper fabricated through a filtration-evaporation approach, and revealed that the LiPSs shuttle effect can be significantly suppressed [157]. Finally, a capacity decay rate as low as 0.014% after 1500 cycles has been achieved. In addition, the hollow and porous merits of hollow porous carbon spheres (HPCSs) could also provide sufficient space for sulfur loading [158]. Combining 0D HPCSs and 2D Ti3C2 MXene, the resulting HPCSs@d-Ti3C2 could not only accommodate volume expansion, but also prevent the aggregation of HPCSs, thereby extending the lifetime of Li-S batteries. Aimed at the neglected problem of Li ion transport for high-rate Li−S batteries, Zhang’s group prepared a flexible free-standing S@lithium-ion-intercalated V2C MXene/rGO-CNT (S@V2C-Li/C) electrode to solve [159], the as-prepared S@V2C-Li/C electrode demonstrated weak capacity decay rates of 0.053 and 0.051% over 500 cycles at different current densities. Furthermore, the additive-free Li2S cathode (Li2S@MXene/G) can be delivered high areal capacities of 5.04 mAh cm−2 at high Li2S loading (up to 9 mg cm−2) in Li–S batteries [160]. Especially, it proved the potential of this high-capacity cathode in the development of Li-free metal rechargeable batteries with high specific energy. The introduction of a functional intermediate layer between separator and sulfur cathode or a coating layer on the cathode side can restrict the shuttle of polysulfides. Song et al. reported a functional separator that is used to capture soluble polysulfides by coating Ti3C2T x nanosheets on commercial PP films, thereby improving the cycle stability and rate performance of Li−S batteries [161]. Eggshell membrane (ESM) is rich of hydroxyl and amine functional groups, which have a strong affinity to lithium polysulfides. A multi-functional separator MXene/ESM composed of MXene debris coated ESM was prepared by Yin et al. (Fig. 10f–h) [162]. For Li−S batteries, with a ketjen black/S (KJC/S) cathode and a Li metal anode, it significantly enhanced the cycling stability with a capacity retention rate of 74% after 250 cycles at 0.5C and presented a discharge capacity of 1321, 1112, 1003, and 948 mAh g−1 from 0.1C to 1C, respectively. Furthermore, the N-Ti3C2/C coated PP separator helped Li−S batteries, it could also provide a high and stable areal capacity of 6.3 mAh cm−2 under a higher S loading more than 10 mg cm−2 (Fig. 10i and j) [163]. In particular, the uniformly decorated zeolitic imidazolate frameworks (ZIF-67) with porous structures retained sufficient active surface exposed on the MXene nanosheets for chemical adsorption, and offered the N and C sources. The above studies indicated that 2D MXene can effectively inhibit the shuttle of polysulfides and enhance the performance of Li−S batteries. In addition, Li et al. reported a series of Ti3C2T x -PP modified separators with different thickness between 1.2 μm (0.16 mg cm−2) and 100 nm (0.016 mg cm−2) [164]. The result suggested that the Li-ion diffusion coefficient enhanced with the reduction of Ti3C2T x layers on the separator. 4.3 Na and K ion batteries Since Na+ and K+ have similar chemistry properties to Li+, they have been extensively researched, and they are abundant in the earth’s crust, making them cheap. However, compared with Li (0.76 Å), the large ionic radii of both Na (1.02 Å) and K (1.38 Å) limits the choice of host materials for them. MXene-based material is expected to achieve high rate capability, because the calculation and experimental results indicated that Na+ and K+ ions have a lower diffusion barrier and a relatively faster intercalation rate between the MXene layers, and form single-layer and double-layer mixtures with surface functional groups through redox chemical reaction [165]. Zhao et al. composited NiCoP nanoparticles prepared by hydrothermal and phosphating processes with alkalized 3D crinkled porous Ti3C2 framework [166]. As displayed in Fig. 11 a, The unique MXene structure effectively relieves volume expansion and prevents the aggregation and crushing of NiCoP nanoparticles, the composite Ti3C2/NiCoP exhibited excellent electrochemical performance with a specific capacity of 261.7 mAh g−1 at 1 A g−1 for 2000 cycles. Based on the alkali or acid induction [167], MXene-derived heterostructures, such as NaTi8O13/NaTiO2 nanoribbons/Ti3C2 [168], Na0.23TiO2 nanobelt/Ti3C2 [75], NaTi1.5O8.3 and K2Ti4O9 nanoribbons [169] were prepared. The sandwich-like Na0.23TiO2/Ti3C2 anodes exhibited superior long cycling stability (up to 4000 cycles at 2 A g−1) for SIBs [75]. Ti3C2 MXene-derived utra-thin (<11 nm) sodium titanate nanoribbons (M−NTO, NaTi1.5O8.3) and potassium titanate nanoribbons (M−KTO, K2Ti4O9) were fabricated by a simultaneous oxidation and alkalization Ti3C2 [169]. A wonderful reversible capacity of 191 mAh g−1 at 0.2 mA g−1 for SIBs was acheived; M−KTO electrode offered superior K storage with high reversible capacity of 191 mAh g−1 at 0.2 mA g−1 and long cycling life > 900 times. In addition, in situ formation of NaTi2(PO4)3 cubes on Ti3C2, and TiO x N y nanoparticles/C composites derived from Ti3C2T x were empolyed as anode materials for Na and K ions storage, respectively [170]. MXene-derived 3D carbon nanotube network encapsulate CoS2 nanoparticles (CoS2/CNTs/TiO x N y ) heterostructurewas provided by Tao et al. [171], as described in Fig. 11b, the CoS2/CNTs/TiO x N y possessed a charge capacity of 403 mAh g−1 at 0.1 A g−1 for solid-state sodium-ion batteries (SSIBs) (Fig. 11c and d). Carbon coated TiS2 nanosheets as another Na-ion storage material were synthesized by in-situ conversion of PVP modified Ti3C2T x MXene (TiS2@Cpvp) and presented outstanding electrochemical performance for Na-ion storage [172]. In the MXene-bonded hard carbon (HC) flms, as displyed in Fig. 11e–f, the HC particles are embedded in the 3D conductive network constructed by 2D MXene nanosheets [173]. Benefting from the network, the MXene-bonded HC film electrodes displayed exceptional rate capability. In addition, wasp nest-imitated assembly of elastic rGO/p-Ti3C2T x MXene-cellulose nanofibers for high-performance SIBs [174]. After that, Fang et al. discovered that TiO2/rGO composites could be generated in situ by hydrothermal treatment of Ti2C/rGO [175]. The nano-size of TiO2 nanoparticles (15–25 nm) with short K+ diffusion path were embedded in the rGO nanosheets with high conductivity to form a composite with a sandwich sheet-like structure. The resulting TiO2/rGO displayed a remarkable electrochemical performance with an outstanding capacity of 104 mAh g−1 at 1.0 A g−1 and the cycling retention of 85% remains after 1000 cycles for PIBs. Furthermore, many metal sulfides and oxides have been extensively studied as common anode materials for SIBs and PIBs. However, they also have disadvantages such as low initial coulombic efficiency, large hysteresis, poor cyclability and severe volume expansion. In order to solve these issues, Zhang’s group reported the MoS2/Ti3C2T x composite that MoS2 nanosheets in situ intercalated between Ti3C2T x layers [176,177]. As anodes, this hierarchical architecture yielded high specific capacity of 250.9 mAh g−1 over 100 cycles for SIBs and 290.7 mAh g−1 at 50 mA g−1 for PIBs. Similarly, combined the metallic conductive of MXene and high redox activity SnS2, Wu et al. fabricated the heterolayered structure of MXene/SnS2 nanoplates via vacuum-assisted filtration, the MXene/SnS2 composite as anode for SIBs with a superior cycling (a reversible capacity of 120 mAh g−1 after 125 cycles) could still obtain at 0 °C [178]. In addition, many groups devoted their effort to exploring the Na/K storage performance of nanoparticles loaded with MXene. For example, Xu’s group anchored the ultrafine CoS nanoparticles (~6 nm) and Bi2S3 nanoparticles uniformly on the Ti3C2 MXene flakes to form CoS/MXene and Bi2S3/MXene composite materials for the first time [179,180]. CoS/MXene as electrode for SIBs provided a high reversible capacity of 267 mAh g−1 at 2 A g−1 after 1700 cycles, and achieved an extremely low attenuation rate of ~0.0072%. Additionally, the FeS2@MXene nanohybrid delivered a considerable specific capacity (563 mAh g−1, 0.1 A g−1) after 100 cycles for Na storage [145]. Due to the MXene nanosheets have good flexibility, it can be encapsulated on the outside of the titanium oxide spheres (TiO2@Ti3C2T x ), Ti3C2T x played a role in stabilizing the volume change of TiO2 sphere during charging/discharging, thereby increasing the cycle stability of TiO2@Ti3C2T x (Fig. 11h, i) [181]. The Sb2O3/Ti3C2T x composite prepared by a facile solution-phase method has a hierarchical structure [182]. As anode in SIBs, an outstanding rate a capacity of 295 mAh g−1 at 2 A g−1 and a superb cycling performance (472 mAh g−1 at 100 mA g−1 after 100 cycles) were achieved. In addition, a 3D flower-like VO2/MXene hybrid architecture anode with superior performance for SIBs [183]. MoSe2 with an interlayer distance of 0.64 nm is favorable for Na/K storage applications. Moreover, compounded with MXene was an effective method to improve whole performance of batteries. MoSe2/MXene@C as a anode for PIBs was fabricated by Zhang’s group [184], the highly conductive MXene substrate can effectively relieve the aggregation of MoSe2 nanosheets and improve the electronic conductivity, the resulting MoSe2/MXene@C achieved a high reversible capacity and wonderful rate performance (Fig. 11j). Based on the theoretical study, the BP/Ti3C2 composite electrode offered excellent specific capacity and cycle stability in SIBs [52]. Furthermore, BPQD anchored on Ti3C2 nanosheets (TNS) achieved brilliant capacity and stable energy storage [81]. The novel 2D/2D heterojunction of FePS3@MXene composite was obtained by liquid ultrasonic exfoliation [185]. Such unique nanostructure could promote rapid reaction kinetics, prevented electrode pulverization and agglomeration for the volume expansion, and provided the pseudocapacitive contribution. 4.4 Mg-based batteries Compared to the monovalent ions (Li+, Na+ and K+), the rich content of Mg2+ ions has about twice the charge density and is able to obtain about twice the theoretical gravimetric capacity. However, cathode material is the key factor which restricts the development of rechargeable magnesium batteries (RMBs) [186–188]. New cathode materials are being seeked and development. For MXenes, the theoretical Mg storage capacities can achieve 580 ~ 1050 mA h g−1 [49], and the intercalated CTA+ cations induce charge transfer from CTA+ to MXene and reduce the diffusion barrier of Mg2+ on the Ti3C2T x surface (Fig. 12 a, b). Consequently, the Ti3C2T x /CTAB electrode exhibited an impressive volumetric specific capacity and a wonderful rate performanc (Fig. 12c) [189]. Similarly, the intercalation of C nanospheres with CTA+ positively charged expanded the interlayer spacing of Ti3C2T x nanosheets [190]. Li et al. used MXene Ti3C2 as an ideal substrate material for supporting active TiS2 [191]. Compared with pure TiS2 cathode material, TiS2/MXene-Ti3C2 composite displayed a build-up capacity of 97 mAh g−1 at 50 mA g−1 for Mg batteries. In Mg-based battery, as an alternative to developing cathode materials for the intercalation of Mg ions, the Mg-Li hybrid battery (MLHB) system, has been widely researched in recent years. Yury’s group reported a free-standing and flexible Ti3C2T x /CNT composite “paper” possessed ~ 100 mAh g−1 at 0.1C [192], as shown in Fig. 12d–f. Moreover, considering the diversity of MXene, this work lays the foundation for exploring a large number of high performance MXenes as MLHB cathode materials. Subsequently, prelithiated V2C was demonstrated that it delivered a considerable reversible capacity and a long cycling life (>480 cycles) in the MLHB [193]. The emergence of magnesium-based hybrid batteries has promoted the further development of Mg batteries, and more works are needed to explore this field in the future. 4.5 Zn and Al batteries For Zn-ion batteries (ZIBs), it possesses attractive theoretical specific capacity (820 mAh g−1), low redox potential of Zn/Zn2+ (−0.76 V vs SHE), the non-flammable and environmental friendly aqueous electrolytes, and so on [194]. However, it is difficult to realize reversible insertion/extraction of divalent Zn2+ in the cathode materials. The Mn3O4/Ti3C2 composite electrode for zinc-air batteries was reported by Xue et al.[195]. As displayed in Fig. 13 a–c, the Mn3O4/Ti3C2 with high conductivity had not a significant potential drop in the constant current discharge curve, and exhibited no change in the 100 h durability test at 10 mA cm−2. Analogous to Mg and Zn, Aluminium (Al) batteries can approximately deliver a four-times higher volumetric capacity (8046 mAh cm−3) than Li metal (2062 mAh cm−3). In theory, Al3+ have more considerable capacity on pure or O-terminated MXenes [49]. V2CT x and Fe2CS2 MXenes could become a desirable electrode for Al-ion batteries [196,197]. Furthermore, the Ti-S bond played a supporting role in maintaining the original structure of the material, as depicted in Fig. 13d [198]. Therefore, the Al-ion battery with the layered composite cathode D-Ti3C2T x @S@TiO2 showed the wonderful first charge/discharge specific capacities (Fig. 13e) and the outstanding discharge specific capacity after 120 cycles (Fig. 13f). In addition, for rechargeable Al batteries, the composite 2D layered structure (Ti3C2@CTAB-Se) was more conducive to the surface adsorption and diffusion of AlCl4 −. Thereby, Ti3C2@CTAB-Se exhibited a reversible capacity of 583.7 mAh g−1 at 100 mA g−1 [31]. 4.6 Metal anode protection Lithium metal is one of the most promising anode materials for lithium batteries. Unfortunately, uncontrollable lithium dendrites and infinite volume changes can cause short circuits inside the battery, causing serious safety issues. To circumvent above issues, some strategies have been developed. Among them, the use of MXene nanosheets as a substrate for modified metal lithium anodes has been widely studied in recent years. A conductive and lithiophilic 3D MXene/graphene (MG) framework with extremely high Li content (~92% of theoretical capacity) could inhibit the formation of Li dendrites and volume changes (Fig. 14 a) [199]. The MG-based electrode showcased high Coulombic efficiencies (~99%) with a record lifespan up to 2700 h and stable for 230 cycles at 20 mA cm−2. Furthermore, a novel 2D/3D structure by combining MXene and nanoporous Si@carbon (NPSi@C) for Li-metal anode developed by An et al. [200]. Inducing Li nucleation and growth could also be achieved by immobiling single zinc atoms on MXene (Ti3C2Cl x ) layers (Zn-MXene) (Fig. 14b) [201]. In the initial electroplating stage, owing to the large number of zinc atoms, lithium tends to nucleate uniformly on the surface of the Zn-MXene layer, and then due to the strong lightning rod effect at the edge, it grown vertically along the nucleation position to form a bowl-shaped lithium without Li dendrites. Thus, a low overpotential and long cyclic life were obtained (Fig. 14c). By coating amorphous liquid metal nucleation seeds on MXene film, isotropic Li nucleation and uniform Li growth were realized. It is found that liquid metal is stable against MXene, which ensures its amorphous state [202]. MXene-based materials are also suitable for the protection of Na and K metal anodes in Na/K metal batteries [203,204]. CT-Sn(II)@Ti3C2 was prepared by CTAB prepillaring followed by subsequent Sn2+ pillaring [203], the Ti3C2 with larger interlayer space uesd “pillar effect” to accommodate the deposited Na. A stable voltage polarization vibration was obtained with a low overpotential (≈180 mV) at 8 mA cm−2, and the Na3V2(PO4)3/CT-Sn(II)@Ti3C2/Na full cell exhibited exceptional rate capability (Fig. 14d–f). A fibrous hydroxylated MXene/carbon nanotubes (h-Ti3C2/CNTs) composite as flexible and stable 3D matrix to guide the uniform Na nucleation with dendrite-free growth is designed [205]. In this structure, CNTs had film-forming properties and tensile strength; h-Ti3C2 with multiple functional groups helped reduce the nucleation overpotential and induce uniform deposition of Na. Thus, h-Ti3C2/CNTs scaffold exhibited an impressive electrochemical performance. For K anode, Tang et al. rationally designed and prepared a freestanding nitrogen-containing MXene/CNT (DN-MXene/CNT) scaffold [204], as depicted in Fig. 14g–i. Thanks to the high electronic conductivity and fast K ion diffusion, DN-MXene/CNT can effciently reduce local current density and facilitate homogeneous K ionic flux, leading to improved rate performance. Furthermore, 3D conductive Ti3C2T x MXene-melamine foam (MXene-MF) with fast electronic and ionic transport channels and excellent mechanical toughness was considered to be an elastic scaffold for dendrite-free, high-areal-capacity alkali anodes (Li, Na, K) (Fig. 14j–l) [206]. A high current density for Li/Na anode and the flat voltage profiles for 800 h at 5 mA cm−2 for the K anode were achieved. These works can offer new avenues for developing alkali metal-based batteries. In general, due to their pseudocapacitive characteristics, a large number of MXene-based heterostructure anodes have been applied for supercapacitors. Compared with graphite, MXene᾿s own larger layer spacing gives it a greater advantage in accommodating Li+, Na+ and K+ ions, and it also has potential competitiveness in terms of theoretical capacity. However, in most cases, complete intercalation is diffusion-limited. Therefore, designing to effectively increase the interlayer spacing of MXene sheets, improve ion channels and prevent sheet re-stacking is the direction of the future efforts. As an electrode for Mg, Zn and Al ion batteries, MXene has a high theoretical capacity; however, owing to major problems in the broader field of multivalent metal ion energy storage, the research is still in the early stages of development so far. In view of the high theoretical capacity and wide interlayer spacing of MXene, they should still be a viable choice for electrode materials with the development of research on Mg, Zn and Al ion batteries. Furthermore, MXene as a metal anode protective substrate is mainly based on two aspects: one is that the interlayer spacing offers enough space for the nucleation of metal ions (Li+, Na+, K+); the other is that the excellent electrical conductivity and abundant lithiophilic functional groups (–O, –OH, –F) on the MXene surface provide an ideal platform for metal ions deposition. In view of the above advantages, the MXene matrix inhibits the growth of dendrites to a large extent, thereby achieving excellent electrochemical performance. 5 Conclusions and perspectives In summary, we have systematically reviewed recent advances in the construction of various MXene heterostructures as electrode materials. The physicochemical properties of MXene heterostructures were introduced from the theoretical prediction, followed by a discussion of their synthesis methods. Thereafter, the applications of MXene heterostructures in energy storage (including SC, Li-based batteries, SIBs, PIBs, Mg-based batteries, Zn and Al ion batteries) and metal anode protection were summarized and discussed, especially focusing on analyzing the performance enhancement mechanisms. As state-of-the-art energy-storage materials, the electrochemical performance of MXene heterostructures materials mainly depend on their structure and interface characteristics. According to the theoretical prediction, the structural design and material multifunctionalization mainly have the following three aspects: expand the interlayer spacing, adjust the surface-terminal-group, and functional composite modification. In these ways, the purpose of improving the electrochemical performance of the material is achieved. Although some progress has been achieved for MXene heterostructures, considering the increasing interest in MXene research and the importance of preparing MXene heterostructures with excellent electrochemical properties, therefore, future research on MXene should focus on the following aspects: (i) Further optimize the synthesis of MXene heterostructure, precisely regulate the content, shape and size of each component in the MXene heterostructure; (ii) The applications about energy storage were predicted by computations, the theoretical predictions of MXene heterostructure in various electrochemical devices needs to be confirmed in future experiments; (iii) As for the energy storage mechanism of MXene heterostructure, it is possible to characterize and elaborate in depth from more aspects. Finally, We believe that more types of MXene heterostructures will be designed in the near future, and these heterostructures can exert great potential in many fields. Sun, ACS Nano, 14 (2020) 867-876. Fanfan Liu is a Ph.D. student with the supervision of Prof. Li-Zhen Fan at the University of Science and Technology Beijing. She received her M.S. degree from Henan Polytechnic University in 2017. Her current research is focused on MXene-based electrode materials and their application in the field of rechargeable magnesium batteries. Sen Jin received his B.S. degree in the School of Electrical Engineering and Automation and M.S. degree in the School of Materials Science and Engineering, Henan Polytechnic University. He is currently a Ph.D. student at Henan Polytechnic University. His main research focuses on the properties of MAX phases, the synthesis and applications of MXenes. Qixun Xia received his Ph.D. in Materials Science and Engineering from Pusan National University (Busan, South Korea) in 2018. After that, He joined the School of Materials Science and Engineering at Henan Polytechnic University where he is currently a lecturer. His current research interests include the synthesis and characterization of new MXenes and their applications in energy storage devices particularly for the supercapacitors. Aiguo Zhou received B.S. degree from Wuhan University of Technology, M.S degree from Tsinghua University (Beijing, China), and Ph.D. degree from Drexel University (Philadelphia, PA, USA). He is Taihang professor of School of Materials Science and Engineering, Henan Polytechnic University. He does research on the synthesis and properties of ternary carbides/nitrides MAX phases and two-dimensional MXene. His research on MXenes focuses on the preparation of novel MXenes from MAX phases. Prof. Li-Zhen Fan is director of Advanced Energy Materials Lab of the University of Science and Technology Beijing. She received her Ph.D. degree in Materials Science and Engineering from Tsinghua University in 2004. She worked as a postdoctoral research fellow at Kyushu University from 2004 to 2005, and then she worked as an Alexander von Humboldt fellow at the Max Planck Institute for Solid State Research from 2005 to 2007. She was a visiting scholar of Prof. John B. Goodenough’s group in The University of Texas at Austin from 2014 to 2015. Her research interest focuses on materials and devices for energy storage.

coredata.dc:description: MXenes are a family of two-dimensional (2D) transition metal carbides, carbonitrides/nitrides with superior physical and chemical properties, which have attracted extensive attention since the discovery in 2011. The impressive electrochemical activity of MXene makes it one of the most potential electrode materials in rechargeable batteries and supercapacitors. However, single-component MXene electrodes are difficult to achieve high specific capacity, efficient ion/electron transport, and high stability compatibility in an electrochemical environment. Studies have shown that it is an effective method to introduce nanomaterials between MXene layers to construct heterostructures and to improve the electrochemical performance through the synergistic effect among the components in the heterostructures. The introduction of nanomaterials can effectively suppress the restacking of MXene nanosheets, shorten the diffusion path of ions and promote the electrolyte transport, which is beneficial to enhance the rate performance of MXene; moreover, the excellent mechanical flexibility of MXene can reduce the volume expansion of nanomaterials during charge/discharge, thereby effectively protecting the integrity of the electrode structure and improving the cycling stability. Therefore, in this review, combined with theoretical calculations, we summarize the recent advances of MXene heterostructures in terms of synthesis strategies and energy storage applications, including supercapacitors, metal-ions batteries (Li, Na, K, Mg, Zn, Al) and metal anode protection. Furthermore, potential challenges and application perspectives for MXene heterostructures are also outlined.
